para.paratext: The court may judicially notice facts of common knowledge that are known to be certain and indisputable or that are subject to verification.[1]

A judge is “refreshing the judicial memory” when he consults a source regarding a fact. This is entirely a fiction since the judge may take judicial notice of a fact which he never knew before. The judge has broad discretion in taking judicial notice, especially in areas where he will refer to a source to refresh his judicial recollection. A judge should never take judicial notice of any fact that may be disproved.[2] Once a court takes judicial notice, a party may not introduce contrary evidence.[3] The court may take judicial notice in situations like ruling on motions where evidence could not be used. The court will disregard any allegation that contradicts anything of which the court took judicial notice. This may result in dismissal of the petition.[4]

The judge should not take judicial notice of a disputed fact, but jurisdictions vary on when there is a dispute. For example, the Georgia Court of Appeals dismissed a petition on demurrer because a trial court took judicial notice of the fact that a train headlight and automobile headlights would cross each other without effect.[5] A federal court refused to take judicial notice of the same fact.[6]

The cases in this area cover many areas of human experience. For example, it is common knowledge that: kerosene is used for cooking, heating, and lighting purposes;[7] scatter rugs have a tendency to slide on a smooth surface;[8] excessive use of intoxicants impairs the operator of a motor vehicle,[9] “an automobile is a heavy metal vehicle, and for it to be overturned upon the person of a female would likely crush and inflict serious or mortal wounds upon her”;[10] and “termination of pregnancy” means the pregnancy ended by abortion or miscarriage.[11] Our common knowledge includes laws of nature and the effect of natural forces,[12] geographical facts,[13] historical facts,[14] statistical facts,[15] abbreviations,[16] calendar,[17] certain customs and usages,[18] and the intoxicating character of certain alcoholic beverages.[19] The Georgia Court of Appeals authorized a trial court to take judicial notice of the recent deaths of the trial judge and his court reporter because it was a matter of public knowledge and it satisfied the requirements of O.C.G.A. § 50-2-21(b)(5).[20]
In a prosecution for driving under the influence of alcohol, a trial court may judicially notice that the standardized horizontal gaze nystagmus test has been verified.[21]
Sometimes, the court may need to consult reference sources to ascertain a fact, especially for scientific facts or principles[22] and medical facts.[23]
Especially for scientific facts, counsel should have a source of information available for the judge before making a request for judicial notice.

In ascertaining a fact, the judge may resort to any helpful source of knowledge, but should not introduce the source into evidence. Two Georgia cases might cause some confusion here. In Fields v. Jackson,[24] the trial court admitted a letter from the Director of the U. S. Naval Observatory stating the time of sunrise on a particular day. The Georgia Court of Appeals held that admitting the letter was harmless error since the court could consult an almanac or other source and could take judicial notice of the time of sunrise on a given day. Oddly, Pentry v. Addison[25] cited the Fields case as holding that the court could introduce the almanac or other source into evidence after it took judicial of the time of sunrise.

Some areas that are not candidates for judicial notice are the prime rate of interest since the prime rate fluctuates and the particular prime rate at any given moment is not the type of fact normally found within a person's “general knowledge and experience”[26] and the operation of the locking device on a cement truck chutes.[27]

City of Bainbridge v. Cox, 83 Ga. App. 453, 64 S.E.2d 192 (1951) (decay of trees); Armor Gas Corp. v. Davis, 93 Ga. App. 563, 92 S.E.2d 244 (1956) (escape of inflammable gas).

In Cornett v. Agee, 143 Ga. App. 55, 237 S.E.2d 522 (1977), the court took judicial notice of “The Second Law of Thermodynamics,” stating: “The court can take judicial notice of anything in the scientific world scientifically provable.”

In Thornton v. State, 161 Ga. App. 296, 287 S.E.2d 749 (1982), the court said that evidence was not admissible against the “great physical laws of the universe,” relying on Oakes v. State, 201 Ga. 365, 39 S.E.2d 866 (1946), but the testimony in that case was proper.
In Taft v. Taft, 209 Ga. App. 499, 433 S.E.2d 667 (1993), the court refused to take judicial notice that bulls, as a class, are dangerous.

Central R.R. v. DeBray, 71 Ga. 406, 1883 WL 2712 (1883) (location of named town in certain county); Stanford v. Bailey, 122 Ga. 404, 50 S.E. 161 (1905) (boundaries and locations of counties); Benton v. Munday, 183 Ga. 228, 187 S.E. 874 (1936) (location of land lot lines); Harmon v. Harmon, 209 Ga. 474, 74 S.E.2d 75 (1953) (cannot take judicial notice of location of streets in the City of Atlanta), followed in Collins v. State, 172 Ga. App. 100, 321 S.E.2d 823 (1984). See Buice v. Satellite Sec. Corp., 156 Ga. App. 348, 274 S.E.2d 608 (1980) (same as in Harmon case as to streets in College Park).

In Phillips v. Abel, 141 Ga. App. 291, 233 S.E.2d 384 (1977), there was no evidence that northwest quadrant of Atlanta was not in Fulton County, so street address with “N. W.” added fixed venue and may have been judicial notice. See Judicial notice as to location of street address within particular political subdivision, 86 A.L.R.3d 484 as to judicial notice of location of street address.

Williams v. State, 67 Ga. 260, 1881 WL 3365 (1881) (Sherman's march to the sea); Railey v. United Life & Acc. Ins. Co., 26 Ga. App. 269, 106 S.E. 203 (1921) (sinking of transport Otranto); State Mut. Ins. Co. v. Harmon, 72 Ga. App. 117, 33 S.E.2d 105 (1945) (existence of a state of war).

Tift v. Bush, 209 Ga. 769, 75 S.E.2d 805 (1953) (official U. S. census figure); City of East Point v. Henry Chanin Corp., 210 Ga. 628, 81 S.E.2d 812 (1954) (population of city); Studstill v. Gary, 216 Ga. 268, 116 S.E.2d 213 (1960) (population of county).
Towler v. Carithers, 4 Ga. App. 517, 61 S.E. 1132 (1908) (N. P.); Becker v. Humphries, 34 Ga. App. 644, 130 S.E. 379 (1925) (M. D.).

Preston v. National Life & Acc. Ins. Co., 196 Ga. 217, 26 S.E.2d 439, 148 A.L.R. 897 (1943) (cancer is a dangerous disease); Metropolitan Life Ins. Co. v. Milton, 74 Ga. App. 665, 92 S.E.2d 567 (1956) (will not take judicial notice of progress of disease or incidence of illness). See 72 A.L.R.2d 554 (1960).
Fields v. Jackson, 102 Ga. App. 117, 115 S.E.2d 877 (1960).

In State v. Dancy, 297 N.C. 40, 252 S.E.2d 514 (1979), the trial judge refused to take judicial notice of the moon condition based on the “Ladies Birthday Almanac.” The Supreme Court did take judicial notice, based on records of the U.S. Naval Observatory. This was a “Lincolnesque” case, since a witness had identified the defendant because the moon was shining bright at 9:45 P.M. on January 30, 1978. The Supreme Court reversed, based on their judicial notice that on that night the moon was in the last quarter and did not rise until midnight.
